name: Whataboutism
definition: Responding to criticism by pointing to someone else's behavior rather than addressing the original point.
whyItWorks: Instead of answering, you make your accuser defend themselves. It feels fair ('why pick on me?'), but you still never answered the question.

examples.text: You're mad I didn't text back? What about when YOU ghosted the group chat for two days last month?
examples.analysis: Their past behavior doesn't answer whether you should have responded. You're just changing the subject.

examples.text: You're upset I was on my phone during dinner? You're on your laptop for work all the time!
examples.analysis: Their screen time doesn't justify yours. Both could be problems, but the deflection avoids the actual conversation.

examples.text: You want to talk about my grades? What about how your grades were when you were my age?
examples.analysis: Dragging up their past doesn't answer the question about how you're doing now.

examples.text: You're criticizing influencer health claims? Pharmaceutical companies have killed way more people with opioids.
examples.analysis: True, but doesn't make bad health advice okay. Two wrongs don't make a right.

examples.text: Concerned about prison conditions? What about the victims who suffer because of these criminals?
examples.analysis: Both deserve concern. Caring about one doesn't mean ignoring the other—deflection just avoids the question.

examples.text: Young people complaining about housing prices? Try buying a house with 18% interest rates like Boomers did.
examples.analysis: Different challenge, different context. Pointing to the past doesn't address today's problem.

examples.text: You're worried about political violence on our side? What about when their side used violent rhetoric last year?
examples.analysis: Past problems on the other side don't answer concerns about what's happening now.

examples.text: You say we cancel people too harshly—what about all the times no one was punished at all?
examples.analysis: Bringing up the opposite problem doesn't evaluate whether current reactions are fair.

examples.text: You care about immigrants now? What about homeless veterans?
examples.analysis: We can care about more than one group at a time. Pointing to another issue dodges the original question.

examples.text: You're asking influencers to show evidence? What about all the unhealthy foods the government still allows?
examples.analysis: Pointing to a different inconsistency doesn't answer whether this specific claim needs evidence.

promptStarters: Before we criticize this, let's talk about how ___ did ___.
What about when ___ happened? Where was the outrage then?
But ___ is just as bad, if not worse!
Funny how no one mentions ___ when they bring this up.
